page.title: 03Geology
page.content: Todmorden lies at the confluence of two glacial valleys, which were formed at the end of the last ice-age by glacial melt waters.These valleys are deep, narrow and have steep sides.The River Calder flows through a gorge, which is a glacial overflow channel, and joins Walsden Water in the centre of Todmorden. The rocks are almost entirely made of Millstone Grit and Shale.As it's name suggests Millstone Grit, which is a kind of very hard sandstone, was once used in mills to grind corn.It is impervious and provides good sites for reservoirs.Dozens of reservoirs on the moors around Todmorden have been used to provide water for water wheels in mills, drinking water and for topping up the Rochdale Canal.Millstone Grit also provives the distinctive building stone in this part of the Pennines.
